unnormalised: Okay guys, so I just got back from an insane train journey across India and I HAD to share the deets. I'm talking about a proper backpacking trip, covering like, 2000+ kms on Indian Railways. Forget flying, train travel is the real deal if you wanna see this country!
normalised: Okay guys, so I just got back from an insane train journey across India and I had to share the details. I'm talking about a proper backpacking trip, covering like, two thousand plus kilometers on Indian Railways. Forget flying, train travel is the real deal if you wanna see this country!

unnormalised: First things first, booking the tickets. I tried to be all fancy and book a 1AC ticket on the Rajdhani, but seriously, ₹5000+ is a bit steep when you're on a budget. Ended up going with sleeper class. And honestly, sleeper class is where the magic happens! It’s like, ₹800 from Delhi to Mumbai, totally worth it.
normalised: First things first, booking the tickets. I tried to be all fancy and book a one A-C ticket on the Rajdhani, but seriously, rupee five thousand plus is a bit steep when you're on a budget. Ended up going with sleeper class. And honestly, sleeper class is where the magic happens! It's like, rupee eight hundred from Delhi to Mumbai, totally worth it.

unnormalised: I preponed my trip from 2/08/2024 as my frnd wasn't free then. Started from New Delhi Railway Station at 6:00 PM. The sheer chaos is amazing! People rushing, chai wallahs shouting, the smell of samosas… it’s a sensory overload. But in a good way, y’know?
normalised: I preponed my trip from second August two thousand and twenty four as my friend wasn't free then. Started from New Delhi Railway Station at six P-M. The sheer chaos is amazing! People rushing, chai wallahs shouting, the smell of samosas… it's a sensory overload. But in a good way, you know?

unnormalised: My first train was the Paschim Express to Jaipur. Reached in like, 4 hrs. Rajasthan is beautiful, man! Everything is so colourful. Next up was the Golden Temple Mail from Jaipur to Amritsar. I reached Amritsar on 05/08/2024 at 10:00 AM.
normalised: My first train was the Paschim Express to Jaipur. Reached in like, four hours. Rajasthan is beautiful, man! Everything is so colourful. Next up was the Golden Temple Mail from Jaipur to Amritsar. I reached Amritsar on fifth August two thousand and twenty four at ten A-M.

unnormalised: The best part about train journeys in India? The food! Forget the overpriced railway catering. You gotta get off at random stations and try the local delicacies. I had aloo tikki in Tundla Junction (seriously, Tundla Junction!), amazing lassi in Punjab, and some questionable but delicious biryani somewhere in MP.
normalised: The best part about train journeys in India? The food! Forget the overpriced railway catering. You gotta get off at random stations and try the local delicacies. I had aloo tikki in Tundla Junction (seriously, Tundla Junction!), amazing lassi in Punjab, and some questionable but delicious biryani somewhere in M-P.

unnormalised: Also, the people! I met a student travelling home for Diwali (which is on 01/11 this year btw!), a retired army guy who told me war stories, and a whole family heading to Kerala for a wedding. Everyone’s so friendly and willing to share their stories. Just keep ur bags safe!
normalised: Also, the people! I met a student travelling home for Diwali (which is on first November this year by the way!), a retired army guy who told me war stories, and a whole family heading to Kerala for a wedding. Everyone’s so friendly and willing to share their stories. Just keep your bags safe!

unnormalised: One thing I learned is always carry toilet paper. And hand sanitizer. Seriously. You'll thank me later. Also, download some movies to your phone because sometimes the wifi decides to take a holiday. I also bought a 20000 mAH power bank. Super useful!
normalised: One thing I learned is always carry toilet paper. And hand sanitizer. Seriously. You'll thank me later. Also, download some movies to your phone because sometimes the wi-fi decides to take a holiday. I also bought a twenty thousand m-A-H power bank. Super useful!

unnormalised: Anyways, if you're looking for a real adventure, ditch the flights and take the train. It's chaotic, it's smelly, it's sometimes uncomfortable, but it's the best way to experience the real India. Just book your tickets in advance on IRCTC, pack light, and get ready for a ride! Total cost for the entire trip was around ₹15000, including food and everything. Bargain!
